review_title: A very good VR FPS experience
one_reviews_text:
MoH gets the core gameplay loop pretty much nailed - excellent gunplay with visceral reloading and the best implementation of two-handed aiming I've seen in VR.

The tone is quite light-hearted. Lots of reviews mentioned an inconsistent tone, but in my opinion it's pretty lighthearted all the way through; the game does not try to be serious outside of The Gallery videos, and it succeeds at being a "fun" game in an era of gritty, emotional, politically charged games.

Aiming with two-handed guns is a case of easy to learn and hard to master. It is very rewarding once you get your eye in with certain guns, looking down their sights, but at first you'll likely dislike it and die a lot. The Thompson is the exception to this as I never really got it to work, and I'd also liked the pistols to be a bit more powerful. Snipers however are great, in the "use the sights realistically" mode anyway. I loved pulling a scope up to my eye and actually holding my breath to take a shot with steady arms.

The graphics are jaw-dropping - not quite as good as Half Life, but the environments are greater in scale. The interactivity is "average" for a VR game; you can pick stuff up but not do much with it.

The sound track is pretty good and has a good few nods to Allied Assault if you happen to remember that after 20 years (or have re-played it recently like I have). In fact, the missions are quite reminiscent of Allied Assualt.

Where the game is weaker is the too frequent cutscenes bringing the game's pacing to a screeching halt - whether this a technical limitation or a developer's tactic to manage nausia / discomfort, I don't know, but especially in the first half of the game you're on the leash a little too much - 3 minutes of in-game cutscene, 5 minutes of walking and shooting, repeat. It improves a lot later in the game.

Also, the enemy AI soldiers have a little too much health and are a little too accurate making for some cheap feeling deaths.

(3700X, 6800XT, Quest 2 via link)

Pros: 

- The map design is good in places, as is the colour palette. 
- The campaign is quite long for a modern game, especially a VR one.
- There are some funny situations, decent one-liners, and lots of camp.

Cons: 

- Tonally inconsistent. Is this a comedy? An homage? A parody? A gritty war epic? The campaign is never believable, gripping or emotionally resonant. 
- It goes out of its way to include Omaha beach and the Western Front when it doesn't even make sense. This setting is already done to death.
- The game handholds a lot.
- Many levels play like linear shooting galleries.
- The weapon and interaction mechanics aren't the worst I've seen but I like to separate VR games into pre-Alyx and post-Alyx, and MOH:AA is VERY much in the pre-Alyx category. You always have to fully reload weapons even if you have a round in the chamber and you don't insert magazines, you move them into an invisible box and let them go with slight delay (yuck). 
- The sound effects and weapon effects aren't realistic.  
- The scale of the levels is wrong, with most objects being unrealistically large (including a Sherman tank that is 20ft high). 
- The NPCs are deep in the uncanny valley. 
- The performance is a mess. I spent a lot of time tinkering on my 2080 Super / Ryzen 5 5600x and there are quite a few framedrops in the campaign despite the game looking very aliased. Much better looking games (Alyx) demand much less of my hardware. I actually bought this game a year ago for different hardware and refunded it, there hasn't been much change since then.
- The install space is 180GB(!). This is the biggest VR game I know of three times over and it's far from being the best looking or most detailed. 
- The AI is atrocious and mostly just runs at the player. The animation transitions are broken so deaths look weird and there's lots of enemies clipping into walls or teleporting into existence as you enter the room. 
- The multiplayer is dead on PC, not sure how good it is.

review_title: Not perfect, but a very enjoyable game!
one_reviews_text:
Despite its flaws I really, really loved this game! It was most likely rushed to release too soon, and I hope the developers get to polish it more through some good updates based on community feedback. It is really sad to think that I almost skipped this game because of the mixed reviews. 

The good: 
I ran the game without any crashes or any big issues on an RX5700XT GPU and Ryzen 7 3700X CPU. 

This is a big VR-game where you get a lot of game for your money, while many other VR-games are mostly very short and limited experiences. You get a campaign that takes about 10 hours to beat, a survival mode to sink hours 
into, multiplayer and a great gallery with really good movies to watch, as well as 360 degrees VR videos of important places in WW2. The campaign has a lot of different locations and different types of gameplay.

This game has some of the most beautiful environments I have ever seen in VR. Extremely immersive at times when the environments look so stunning and you see tanks roll around and planes fly above your head. You really feel the environments are real when you can look far into the distance. Great sound effects for guns as well. Faces mostly look great. The campaign and story is a little over the top and silly, but still great fun! 

The bad:
Enemy AI needs a proper overhaul. Guards often stand for a second after being shot, and fire at a wall if your on the other side of the wall, or fire at the ground
if you are below them. Sizes of characters feels off. My in game hands are way too big. 

I also feel it should be possible to manually reload 100% with all weapons. It is very weird that you can press a button to reload the shotgun. Aiming with your head to use turrets is weird. They need to finish the weapons and have the same level of detail and polish. You should not be locked in place during cutscenes, but be able to walk around. History-buffs like me would love interact with old things while characters talk.

review_title: The game is very fun, but disappointing
one_reviews_text:
Let me explain why it was disappointing to me.
I recommend this game without a doubt, but for its price it should've had more polish.
The graphics are stunning, the gunplay is smooth ( even though the reload mechanics are a bit weird but it still works decently well ), the sound design is great, the voice acting is great, the story is decent ( it feels like old school MH but these games never had a great story ), the ambience is really good too, so why was i disappointed ?
Well, the physics are basically non-existent, for a game that's as expensive as Half Life Alyx and developped by such a big studio you would expect it to have at least basic physics.
The mission pacing is bizarre, some missions are literally 30seconds long and then you get a loading screen and some others are 10-30mins long.
The multiplayer is dead, i usually wouldn't blame a VR game for how much players are playing because there isn't too many people who play VR yet but it's mainly due to the pricing of the game so it's their fault.
I still recommend it as it's a fun game.

From the start, every mission is divided into a multitude of sub-chapters leaving 
you to play for a few minutes in a usually very restricted environment, frequently interrupted by loading screens and way too many scripted events you cannot influence in any way. The whole game therefore feels like a fractured mess of mini arenas loosely connected by lackluster storytelling, extremely stereotypical characters and comedic episodes that simply feel out of place.

Imagine clearing a compound and looking at the deserted place from a roof top only to find it magically repopulated with enemies a few seconds later once you pass an invisible spawn trigger point.

I can forgive the non-existent AI, weapons clipping through objects, weird physics and all the other little things like monstrously large Sherman tanks etc., but not the constant immersion breaking logical errors. Sorry.

This is a very accurate game in the sense of its mechanics and history. The looks of the weapons and scenery depict an accurate setting of the 1940s in WW2, with defenses and homes alike looking like they fit into the time you are playing in. The gameplay, for the most part, is involved and fun, and you are never truly left out of the action. 

Now, I have an over-specced processor for this game, but slighty under-specced GPU for this game, with a Ryzen 9 3900x and an RTX 2070 Super, respectively. However, the gameplay is stuttery most of the time, and is only perfect during scenes where you aren't allowed to move; the narration scenes. Now this could be because of my slightly under-specced GPU but the stuttering is heavy during the gameplay. 

Also, so far throughout my gameplay experience, I have not found out a way to actualy save in-game progress besides completing missions, which sucks since each mission can take quite a long time to beat (30-45 minutes for me). So, if you want to get a quick game of VR in before going out somewhere, this game is not ideal for that particular situation, and, instead, should only be played when you have ample amounts of time and your legs are not tired. 

Also, something the game should have is a crouch button. Now, I know this is a VR game and you can bend down in real life to crouch in-game, but it is an inconvenience, especially during situations where you may have to crouch to hide for a prolonged period of time. Plenty of other VR games have a crouch button implemented into the controls, such as The Walking Dead: Saints and Sinners (My personal favorite VR horror experience). 

To conclude, Medal of Honor: Above and Beyond is an amazing and immersive WW2 VR experience if you can get around the slight graphical errors that occur quite often.

review_title: Not so much AAA+, more like CCC-
one_reviews_text: First things first, if you are expecting something like Battlefield 1 (or V) in VR, move on. This game is inferior in every aspect to the 4 year old Battlefield 1, from graphics to level design to gameplay to acting. This game is essentially a collection of multiple short, linear WW2 set pieces strung together to create 6 main 'levels', most are forgettable but some are pretty good (fighting off ME109's from a B17 is a standout, sniping from a rooftop is also well done). The short nature of each set piece can be jarring which somewhat breaks the VR immersion. Graphically the game ranges from decent to fairly poor (for a game you need over 300gb space to run and upgrade). The NPC's are also pretty poor, looking dated (think pre Skyrim) and some of the voice acting is embarrasing (think Allo Allo). The little English dude with the Harry Potter glasses and mockney accent is so annoying I've tried to shoot him myself a few times. The gunplay is decent and intuitive (you hit what you aim at) and I like the way weapons snap back into place to avoid fumbling/dropping them like in some other VR games, however you still have to charge your weapon again after changing mags even if you still have a round in the chamber, which is pretty lazy as almost every other VR shooter out there doesn't do that. The game installed without issue for me and ran effortlessly from start to finish on an i7 7700 with GTX 1070 Gigabyte P57 gaming laptop. I did need to clear over 300gb for the installation to be able to run upgrades without having to uninstall and reinstall every time. To put that into perspective, that is more space required than any other AAA game I have ever owned, and MOHAAB is not an AAA game. Overall I did have some fun playing the game, but not £46 worth of fun, more like maybe £25 worth, £30 at a push. What would make it better? Larger individual levels, better textures, 2020 style NPC's (as opposed to 2010 style), better voice acting. Overall, 3 stars.

First off, I'd like to say that this game is AMAZING in VR and it runs on my rig at default settings with no issues whatsoever.  I'm running my VR on a ten-year old computer, on which I've only upgraded the Operating System, GPU card, and hard drive.  My PC has an Intel i7 CPU 920 @ 2.67 GHz, 12 GB of DDR3 RAM, NVidia GTX 1070, and a 2 TB SSD.  That being said, it's likely that those having issues are running standard hard disks.  My SSD is probably the most important investment I've ever made for performance, because most games are disk-intensive ... as a result, I've never had any issues with any VR game.  Your PC should be 100% SSD, or it's going to struggle no matter what CPU, GPU, or memory you have.

It's hard to express how different it is playing a WWII shooter in VR versus on a monitor.  The immersiveness is beyond anything I've ever experienced.  You're in a firefight, running behind trucks while people are firing at you and you are (literally!) ducking for cover!  I'm pressed up against a wall and peeking my head out the window to see what's coming down the road.  Some German soldier walks in the room and you become frantic when you realize you need to reload.

MOH puts you right inside of World War II in a way that, frankly, I just was not expecting.  The sense of immersion is amazing and the graphics, sound, and environment in MOH are all terrific.  Even when you are back at your own base learning the basics, there are people and activity all around you.  It really feels like you are in Europe in the early 1940s.  For the first time ever playing a game, I also got an appreciation for just how terrifying it must have been to be in WWII.

I'm still early in the missions, but I can already state that this is worth the $60 price tag.  If you have a decent GPU, a reasonable amount of RAM, and (most definitely) a Solid State Drive ... then you should have a blast with this game!

Passionné de Seconde Guerre Mondiale et des Medal Of Honor (surtout allied assault), j'ai pris mon pied dans la campagne solo. Je ne crois pas avoir vu de missions/environnements aussi variés dans un jeu VR depuis que j'en fais (2017). 

Graphiquement : C'est moins fin qu'un HL:A, mais on peut aisément le comprendre quand on voit dans quels espaces on évolue tout au long de l'aventure. Il ne s'agit ici pas uniquement de couloirs/salles/escaliers mais d'espaces plein air plutôt inspirés : trains, avions, bunkers, Manoirs etc... 
La direction artistique est superbe, les détails sont impressionnants. Se retrouver dans un QG allemand & découvrir des cartes de France d'il y a 60 ans avec des villes & villages qui nous sont familiers, c'est superbe !

Son : Très bonne musique "cinéma" qui colle parfaitement à l'ambiance du jeu et au contexte. Les clins d'oeils aux premiers MoH font plaisir. La musique originale est vraiment impeccable. Les sons ambiants sont parfaits eux aussi. Entre les rafales de MG42, le ping du M1, les cris des soldats, nickel.

Performances : Je joue sur une RTX 2080Ti & un i9 9000k / 32Go RAM

Avec tout à fond, j'ai quelques mini saccades sur certaines missions (notamment niveaux en mouvement) 
A voir avec les patchs à venir, mais il suffit de tweaker un peu les settings et ça le fait :)

Gameplay : 
Franchement, c'est beaucoup plus nerveux & vif qu'un HL:A, en même temps, les séquences de combat sont beaucoup plus nombreuses. La visée est un peu tricky au départ, mais c'est parce qu'il n'y a ici pas de viseur à point rouge ou autre. Il faut vraiment viser à l'ancienne, et ça moi je kiff !
Le smooth moving a été ajouté, le tracking est au top, le rechargement de certaines armes a été simplifié pour plus de fun. Rien à redire.

Multi : Pas encore essayé. 

Jeu sous évalué lors de sa sortie, mais on voit qu'il y a clairement du travail derrière. C'est un incontournable pour moi, même à 52€.

Respawn has released some game updates too.  

This game is fantastic and great visually.  The levels are well designed with excellent attention to detail.  This game is among the most fun I have had in VR, and there were plenty of "Wow!" moments.  The single player campaign is a series of discrete mission scenarios.  They play out like a playable popcorn movie within a story framework based on the WW2 campaign in Europe, with cutscenes mixed in.  The playable scenarios provide a lot of variety in location and gameplay, with picturesque visuals across the landscape.  In watching videos in the WW2 gallery, I was struck by the similarities of the landscapes in the game vs what I saw in the videos on location in France.  

To keep the load times between missions minimal, I would only install this game on an SSD (not a hard drive).  The updates gave graphical options to help provide a smooth experience, added smooth turning, and addressed various concerns raised by the VR community.  
 I am playing the campaign through a 2nd time now that 3d scopes are an option.  They are very good!  There are many options to turn off UI text, mission objectives, etc for a very realistic view.  The game is in a very good place now.
$60 is the same price HL Alyx was at launch and I find this game more fun.  Comparing visual apples to apples (wood, stone, brick, vehicles, etc.), I think this game looks better.

review_title: Not true to the old games.
one_reviews_text:
I do enjoy this game. WW2 content has always been my favorite basis for video games, and the experience of getting to use a Garand or an MP40 to wreck some nazis is wonderful. I do have issues with it though.

This game doesn't quite have the feel of the old Medal of Honor games. In my opinion, Pacific Assault was MoH in its prime. Above and Beyond hasn't been on par so far in almost any respect, other than the fact it's a WW2 game.

The weapon functionality isn't great. For starters, if you fire an SMG the bullets may decide to come out sideways, regardless of the orientation of the weapon. Recoil is not to blame in this case and it doesn't really make sense. It's one of those FPS mechanics that isn't meant for VR. The reload has you pulling the bolt back in all the automatics regardless of the gun's actual remaining ammo count. The shotgun reload doesn't even let you handle the shells and the lever action has the same issue. The Garand apparently has a clip ejection button, instead of actually having to pull the charging handle to eject the remaining rounds.

Finally, the story has been rough. The action is constantly interrupted by "cutscenes" that have you standing around listening to all the other characters. The combat comes in bursts instead of a steady flow. I've heard it will be better in Mission 2, and I'm very nearly there, but so far all these issues have been a bit of a turn-off.

Overall, don't spend $60 if you want a true-to-the-title or mechanically accurate game.

So far into my experience, I will say that the game is decently fun but the price is too steep regardless of the decent amount of content and I have no idea why this file size is so large. Its no Half-life but its not another VR tech demo.

Here are a couple of examples of good/cool features that come bundled with a few poor design choices to illustrate my previous point (these aren't even all of them but just those i can think of off the top of my head):

-Gun machanics are pretty fun with some interesting reload ideas thrown in for the player to have fun with. That said the sniper when aimed will give you a black periphery vision with a centered visible circle for aiming and the sight renders the other side of the scope  in 2D (...why? other shooters have been getting snipers right in VR for years now). Also, your virtual arm gets in the way of some of the sights on your weapons when aiming.

-weapons automatically reholster when dropped, but swapping weapons is a pain since the last selected weapon will be replaced, meaning you have to go back to the weapon you want to get rid of first and then select a new one (doesn't sound bad or complicated but it is immersion breaking and kinda annoying). This mechanic isn't helped by the fact that this game has a habit of making you pick up anything and everything in your vicinity except for the object you are actually aiming to pick up.

-It actually has a story (which is oddly paced, incredibly cheesy, and constantly interrupts the gameplay) and decent voice actors (that are given cringy dialogue and have them edited into the game at odd intervals making conversations seem stilted).

review_title: 3.5 stars Great game... with some issues
one_reviews_text: I love this game, in my opinion one of the best vr games ever. I would love to rate it higher but it simply has too many little things that bother me. Multiplayer needs some work, specifically on the loadouts. I wish we could create a legit loadout (similar to Onward) rather than picking one gun and one "gadget" I guess you would call it. I play this game on a 1660 ti with link and it stutters quite a bit when I launch it but once I get going and play for a bit It becomes smooth as butter. Also I look forward to new guns. There simply aren't enough, especially in multiplayer. Gunplay is very good but its the minor details that hold it back. And any time you enter a turret or an AA gun you controll it based on where you look, not physical controls. This is a huge hit and needs to be changed to either joysticks or in game controls (the nose and tail guns on the b-17 were great) The story is very very good but it feels blocky or chunky with loading screens after almost every encounter (the update may have fixed this, I havent checked.). Very curious about DLCs too. Overall, this game is very good with a few kinks but it has a lot of potential. Im sure that over time it will all get workked out and this will become my top vr game ever.

Just downloading the first patch as i write this review and i cant wait to finish the last mission i still have left. Dear Respawn/Oculus as you asked for feedback here is some more. I am a WW2 militaria collector and though i do not expect every uniform to be correct it would be nice if you could fix a bunch of mistakes i name here. The standard Wehrmacht solider needs to have a swastika on the belt buckle under the eagle + depending on location ammo pouches for the K98K or the MP40, bread bag, gas mask canister etc. and please, the uniform of the main villains hench man, the one you meet again on the ship is fantasy, it makes more sense using a SS officer skin that you already have for his character. The German soldier with the handcuffed briefcase needs to be replaced with an officer. Good job on the Luftwaffe Pilot or some of the Kriegsmarine uniforms :) Loving the game so far and will definitely replay it again on hard difficulty. PS : Please add more collision for objects.

With that out of the way, we can get to reviewing the campaign. I was very impressed at first. I spent a lot of time messing around with all the weapons in the training areas and the gun play is top notch, most of the time. Then I got to a couple oudoor scenes with a lot of foliage and complexity, which caused the visuals to nosedive into the ground. Mostly the game looks wonderful so I'm guesisng my 3600X and 3060 ti don't have enough juice.

Half-Life Alyx this is not; and now that I have been playing Population 1 for weeks, the movement mechanics for both feel antiquated. Pop 1 has full body inverse kenematics (modeling), wheras MoH VR only models your hands with locked wrists. 

So far, it seems like lots of things are out of scale, like character models are ten to fifteen percent too big. I'm 5'9 and all the charcter models, included all women, seem good foot or more taller than me. 

How were so many bad decisions made and retained?! The action sequence missions are essentially crappy barf rollercoasters and there is a level where you climb through a sinking ship that is no joke the worst level in any game I'm played in recent memory.

Ok... so I just played the first half of the Norway mission set and it's so awful I just docked another star. Respawn should apologize for the bad one liners, ongoing shouting by allies during a supposed stealth / sniper misson and a vomit inducing ski sequence. Absolutely pathetic; it should have been scrapped entirely. 

Then the second half of the Norway mission set was incredible. How were these missons made by the same people?!

Additional Feeback: 
1. Why the hell can't I carry a knife on my person? Not being able to holster a knife seems like a horrific oversight. Please add asap. 
2. It took me minutes, plural, to figure out how to load the MG42. It didn't occur to me for far too long that I was suppoed to simply whip out a 250 round ammo can from a magical invisible pouch on my hip belt. 
3. Please add calibration for physical gun stocks like in Contractors!

Buy it if you only care about having an interesting and creative story.
Do not buy it if you care about immersion, Historical accuracy, realism and convenient and yet realistic game mechanics.
For me the biggest turn off what the game mechanics like for example, you strictlly have a rifle class weapon on your left shoulder and an SMG/LMG class weapon on your right + sidearm on your belt holster. Want to run around with an MP40 and and A gewehr 43? nope, game won't let you. 
The ammo system is garbage. Basically you have 3 crates of ammo in the game. 1 for rifles, 1 for SMGs, 1 for pistols. You can use an M1 Garand deep in German territory and have an infinite supply of ammunition available despite Germans not using most calibers the Allies used.
Also the Kar98k has cartridge capacity of 1 round in this game, but also you never actually reload the Kar98k. you bolt it until you actually run out of all of your spare ammo. no 5 round mag with clip insert. just infinte bolting. 
Want to fire just half of your Pistol's or SMG's mag and do quick reload? nope, you reaload and operate the bolt/slide because apparently the developer was too lazy to program that as well. In real life and most FPS games out there, you do not have to operate the slide/bolt of these weapons if the chamber has a round in it. This game doesn't care about that.
Story also makes no strategic sense at times. Like for example Why would the OSS agree to send untis all the way from the UK to stop a train at Schmerzen to stop some insignicant captured French resistance Girl Named Juliette, who is heading for Berlin for special interogation (because apparently all the top ranking Gestapo agents based in France were on their summer vacation apparantely)
The Ai in normal combat sittuation speak perfect German, but in Schmerzen, they spoke English with an accent, while the Sgt. was  practicing his German only to speak English with a fake accent. What gives?tbh this game is worth 2 star,, but im generous.

I have only had this game a short time, but am impressed in most areas so far.  I like the story and the immersiveness is superb.  I like the way they worked in doing the settings as part of the story.  The NPC characters are done very well.  The environment is impressive. Probably the best I have seen in VR except for Half Life: Alyx .  I like the the cut scene interactions as it puts you in the story a little deeper than most shooters.

My only real complaint so far is the interaction with objects seems a little off at times.  It can be difficult to pick up the item you are going for.  You often accidentally grab the one next to it, even if the hand is right one the one you want.  It was really bad in the shooting range at the beginning when trying to pick up grenades from the table.  There were other smaller similar issues.   So far I have played just on my CV1 Rift with 3 ceiling mounted sensors. That is usually the best setup for accurate tracking and it still has this issue.  No other experiences have an issue like that with this setup.  I will try it later on my Quest with Oculus link setup to see if it is any different.

This game is big .  In the system I used so far, the OS is on an SSD, but the game is loaded on a 4TB hard drive.  In some cases the load times seemed a little longer than expected, I am assuming mostly due to the amount of data being loaded and being installed on a large hard drive.   

I have currently only tried it on one PC, 16 GB, Ryzen 7 1700X with an 8GB GTX 1080.  Despite the video card being a generation behind the recomended spec of a GTX 2080, it seemd to run without any issue and looked very impressive.  I will use a different PC when I test in on Oculus Link for comparison.

My experience so far: fix the tracking, then 5 stars.

if you eject a mag that isn't completely empty, and then slap a fresh one in, you still have to rack the slide for some crazy reason (this shouldn't be necessary because there should still be a round in the chamber from the last mag).  You should only have to do this when the last mag was *completely* emptied.

There are plenty of reviews out there to tell you all the other things about this game.  I think it's pretty good overall, some good graphics and gun fights, a few epic moments, but sometimes it just feels a little cheesy and arcady, rather than gritty, scary and and serious, like a war game should feel IMO.  I'm not impressed with the AI, they seem to be only as advanced as the Nazis that I was just killing in Return to Castle Wolfenstein (nearly 20-year-old game).  they like to just stand or run around in the open during a firefight waiting to get hit, and their animations are a little silly looking to me, the way they run esp.  as others have said I wish there was a little more/better physics, and more interaction with the world around you, this feels very much like Asgard's Wrath in how the world around you feels like it's made out of plastic and your hands go through most things.

in the end I think it's still worth it, given the length of the campaign and amount of content, but just barely, due to the price. I mainly just wanted to point out the immersion breaking reloading annoyance that I haven't seen mentioned anywhere else. Should be an easy thing to fix, but will it be?
